posts.post_content: This looks like a slow, powerful, big-mana set. If that's true, then I see no reason why Poly here can't become a role-player in some of the stronger mono-green decks looking to dump their mana into something that will give them an advantage against creatures: the one permanent type green typically has trouble dealing with. As has been said before: give him deathtouch. Give him trample. Guess what? Nylea and her bow do both. I doubt it'll be format-warping or the cornerstone of this set's deck to beat, but Polukranos is not a terrible creature. Not sure he had to be a mythic, legendary hydra, but he's actually quite good.
posts.html:

As has been said before: give him deathtouch. Give him trample. Guess what? Nylea and her bow do both. I doubt it'll be format-warping or the cornerstone of this set's deck to beat, but Polukranos is not a terrible creature. Not sure he had to be a mythic, legendary hydra, but he's actually quite good.

Posted By: Lord_of_Tresserhorn (9/17/2013 4:02:11 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: If he's actually the format-defining superhydra that development believes him to be (right up there with Reckless Waif and...things that aren't Thragtusk), it will be based less on his own merits than on his ability to trigger double devotion. Even then, Deadbridge Goliath would be better, as it remains potentially useful after death and isn't legendary. I'm tired of talking about him being "green board wipe." He's not board wipe, ESPECIALLY when you take into account the amount of high-toughness creatures in Theros block. It takes this guy three mana to kill a goat, and then he will never kill any more goats for as long as he shall live. I mean, other than the ones who chump block him with ruthless efficiency. I get that X-costs are usually inefficient at the lower X values, but...that double-X is just a pain. It won't stop me from trying to make use of him, but I'm just disappointed that I enjoy Mistcutter Hydra, Protean Hydra, and Primordial Hydra more than this legendary mythic hyd... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Posted By: SpaceMagic (9/17/2013 7:14:34 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
When he was spoiled I was terribly unhappy with his monstrous cost of GXX. After playing with him now, I'm okay with it. Yes, its an expensive fireball. But you don't have to pay the 1 extra for each extra target, and with it being green which is the color of ramp, it'll be just as effective as a fireball. And you can activate it at any time, whereas a fireball is a sorcery.  
  
You cannot target players, but I feel like that's not really worth counting as a con. His size pretty much will make up for that.  
   
So after you fireball some problem or utility creatures, you can smash face with a now much larger Polukranos.
posts.html:

posts.post_content:
Am I the only person who has noticed this?  
Monstrous can be used at instant speed.  
What does this mean?  
Use it with [Bow of Nylea](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bow of Nylea).  
It's perfectly on curve, too.  
3 mana -- Bow.  
4 mana -- Polukranos.  
5 mana -- Monstrous for 4G, kill two creatures.

posts.post_content:
This is such a hard card to evaluate. Sure Wizards could have made it better. You can always make things better. But the question then becomes is it good for its rarity? I personally don't think so in this set. Even if this thing was a rare I wouldn't be too worried about it effecting limited too much. Its green removal sure, but its kinda slow. I wanted to use this in commander but the effect is too underwhelming. If it was something like XG: and this ability or XXG: monstrous, X can't be 0 it deals damage equal to its power divided as you choose between any number of targets this would be really good. But in both those cases its extremely strong Green removal. And I'm not sure we really want green to have access to that powerful of removal in constructed or limited.   
  
I get it. Change on thing about it and its solid and extremely powerful removal, leave it as is and its underwhelming. \*Sigh\*. Oh well.
